Chapter I

On a very hot evening in early July, a young man stepped out of the small room he rented in S. Place. He walked slowly, as if unsure, toward K. bridge. 

He had managed to avoid running into his landlady on the stairs. His room was under the roof of a tall, five-story building and was more like a closet than a real room. The landlady, who gave him the room, meals, and help, lived one floor below. Every time he went out, he had to pass her kitchen, which was always open. Each time he walked by, he felt sick and scared, which made him frown and feel embarrassed. He owed a lot of money to his landlady and was afraid of seeing her.

This fear didn’t come from being weak or submissive; in fact, he was the opposite. For a while now, he had been very tense and irritable, almost to the point of being depressed. He had become so focused on himself and cut off from others that he feared meeting not just his landlady, but anyone at all. He was weighed down by poverty, but lately, the worries about his situation didn’t bother him as much. He had stopped caring about important things and lost all desire to deal with them. Nothing his landlady could do really scared him anymore. But to be...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** A young man, burdened by debt and isolation, hesitates to leave his cramped garret, fearing encounters with his landlady and others.
